Transcendental Arguments in Philosophy of Psychology and Perception
8. Concluding Remarks

We have looked in some depth at the role of transcendental arguments
that have been given in philosophy, not only in refuting the
epistemological sceptic, but also in ethics, philosophy of psychology,
and philosophy of perception. As we have seen, such arguments clearly
face challenges, both in their details but also at a more general
level, concerning how much they can ever hope to achieve. However,
while these challenges are certainly significant, it would be wrong to
exaggerate them: for, as we have also seen, the range of potential
uses for such arguments is wide, while it seems that their intriguing
power, as well as their alluring promise, will mean that philosophers
will continue to be drawn to them. As a result, therefore, it seems
unlikely that those engaged in the subject will ever cease to feel
that ‘tenderness for transcendental arguments’ (Strawson
1985: 21) instilled in them by Kant and others.
